Dear Andrea Melendrez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact the area
manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
1

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth has an ongoing history with violence and attacking people,
and police have been involved several times. Youth is being
allowed to play a violent video game called Kick the Buddy and it
involves killing a doll through various methods, exploding it,
destroying it, setting it on fire, shotting it, freezing it, and
electrocuting it. Youth is allowed to play this video game on the
tablet for extended periods of time.
Investigation On 08/30/23 contact was made with the Complainant and no
additional concerns were noted.
On 08/10/23 an in-person visit was made to Adrian Group Home.
The SIR was initiated. An interview was held with Social Worker.
She reported she is the social worker at facility, but is working
additional hours today as a direct care staff. Social Worker
provided history regarding Youth A which included his extensive
trauma history and his current thought of being possessed by
demons. Social Worker confirmed Youth A has access to his
tablet up to two times per day. She denied being aware of the
total time he is using the tablet when access is provided each day,
but confirmed the agency has a schedule that allows for tablet
time for the youth. Social Worker denied there is any policy
relative to the type of games the youth have access to. She
reported the Chief Administrator is the person that selects and
downloads games onto the tablets.
On 08/10/23 a phone call was placed to the Chief Administrator
(CA). CA confirmed Youth A has a tablet, and he has access to it
usually 1 to 2 times per day and it is limited to 30 to 40 minutes.
She further advised a daily schedule is posted that documents the
availability of personal time for the youth. CA also reported she
was aware of the game “Kick the buddy” that is on the tablet of
Youth A. She reported Therapist recently brought it to her
attention but did not express any concerns regarding the game.
CA was advised to refrain from allowing the youth to play “Kick the
buddy” game until the conclusion of the investigation. On
08/17/23 another phone call was held with CA. She advised “Kick
the buddy” and any other games assessed to be inappropriate
had been removed from the tablet of Youth A. She denied ESRB
ratings for video games is used as a tool to determine
appropriateness for youth video games. She also admitted she
was not aware of the blood and violence that was present in the
2

game as it did not “look” like that type of game and seemed to be
more youth friendly. A follow up phone call was made to CA on
9/14/23 where she again confirmed Therapist had not expressed
specific concern regarding the video games being played by
Youth A on his tablet prior to the investigation being initiated. She
later clarified Therapist may have mentioned it one day. She did
not have an explanation as to waiting at least 24 hours to remove
the game from the tablet.
On 08/10/23 an in-person interview was held with Supervisor at
Adrian Group Home. She reported she is a supervisor at the
facility. She described Youth A as a calm youth, but stated lately
he has been more angry. She stated he is currently upset and
yelling because he wants his tablet. She stated he usually only
has the tablet during reflection time for a total of 30 minutes to 1
hour. Supervisor reported she would not describe the youth as
violent, but more traumatized. She reported he states he has
“demons” inside of him and she wonders if he sometimes tries to
use that as an excuse. She stated that she has seen Youth A
play Minecraft, Talking Tom and a racing game on his tablet. He
began playing “Kick the buddy” this week. She reported CA
approves and downloads the games onto the tablets.
On 08/10/23 an in-person interview was held with Staff 3 at
Adrian Group Home. Staff 3 confirmed she is aware of Youth A
being on his tablet. She stated she would not describe the youth
as violent but recalls he did attempt to bite her one time. She
reported he is only supposed to be on the tablet during reflection
time, but some staff give it to the youth other times during the day
if he is well behaved. She described it like a “reward” for the
youth. Staff 3 stated she was aware of him playing “Talking Tom”
and “Minecraft” but was not aware of “Kick the buddy”.
On 08/10/23 an in-person interview was held with Youth B at
Adrian Group Home. She stated she does not have a tablet and
is working on “earning” a tablet by following program. She
reported she is aware that other youth have tablets, including
Youth A. She reported youth usually get access to the tablet
during “reflection” time and sometimes at night. She stated she is
not sure what games the youth play on the tablet but has seen
staff monitoring and checking in with the youth when they have
the table.
On 08/10/23 an in-person interview was held with Youth A at
Adrian Group Home. He reported he plays on his tablet during
reflection time. He listed several games that are his favorites on
3

his tablet, with “Kick the buddy” being one. Youth A wanted to
show off his tablet and games that he plays. He stated he wanted
to show the blood and how he wins the game. Youth A struggled
to remain focused during the interview and became preoccupied
with wanting to play the games on his tablet. He was able to
confirm he sees Therapist at Adrian House but denied that any
staff or therapist suggested that he not play “Kick the buddy”.
Youth A was unable to remain focused and the interview was
concluded.
On 08/10/23 an in-person interview was held with Youth C at
Adrian Group Home. She reported she does not get to utilize a
tablet anymore because she tried to break through the parental
controls. She reported two youth at the agency have tablets and
she is not really sure what games and other apps they have on
the tablet. She denied knowing how often the youth get to use the
tablets, but indicated the staff monitor youth when on the tablet
and indicated this is how they were aware she was attempting to
break the parental controls.
08/16/23 a video conference was. DHHS worker assigned to
Youth A expressed concern regarding him having access to such
a violent game given the trauma in his history. DHHS specialist
denied any reference to Youth A not playing “Kick the buddy” or
other video games as a part of his treatment plan.
On 08/30/23 an video interview was held with Therapist.
Therapist advised she expressed her concern to both the
assigned DHHS Specialist and CA regarding Youth A playing the
video games that she assessed to be violent given his traumatic
history. Therapist further expressed she advised CA on 4-5
occasions and Youth A continued to have access to the video
games. Therapist confirmed there was no reference to the youth
not having access to specific video games as a part of his DHHS
or Adrian Group Home treatment plans. Therapist reported she
had documentation of notification of concern to CA and would
forward it via email. On 9/14/23 Therapist was contacted via
telephone as a follow up regarding documentation of notification to
CA of concern regarding Youth A and video games. She advised
she did not have any written documentation of notification to CA.
Documents/Items Reviewed:
Rating for Kick the Buddy Game is Teen
Service Plan and Treatment Plan of Youth A – history of youth
that included information relative to length of time in care, reasons
4

for entering care and trauma he experienced prior to entering
care. It was also noted treatment plan of youth did not include
information regarding refraining from tablet use or playing video
games on his table.
Amazon Tablet of Youth A on 8/10/23 – Several games were
found to be downloaded onto the tablet, including a game titled
“Kick the buddy”.
Program Statement of Adrian Group Home - Genacross Family
and Youth Services’ primary purpose is to provide residential and
group home care and treatment within the continuum of care to
high-risk clients in open settings.
Staffing Requirements and Supervision Policy - Genacross
ensures that minimum staffing requirements and supervision of
clients is maintained. Ratio of 1:2 during waking hours.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to support violation of licensing rule 400.4109 (1) (c).
The agency does not have a policy or procedure to address youth
access to electronics and content installed. Specifically, the Chief
Administrator admitted that she installed video games to the
tablets of youth without knowledge of or review of ESRB ratings or
consideration of the needs of the youth.
Technical Assistance:
The agency needs to develop and implement a policy that
provides guidance on appropriate video game use for youth in the
facility considering the ESRB Ratings and therapeutic needs of
the youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
